sen.j: 皇大神社（こうたいじんじゃ）は、京都府福知山市大江町に鎮座する神社である。
sen.e: The Kotai-jinja Shrine is located in Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Kotai-jinja Shrine is located in Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.
The Kotai-jinja Shrine is located in Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 近代社格制度は府社。
sen.e: This was categorized as Fusha (a prefectural shrine) in Kindai shakaku seido (Modern shrine ranking system).
It was categorized as Fusha (a prefectural shrine) in Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system).
It was categorized as Fusha (a prefectural shrine) in Kindai shakaku seido (modern shrine ranking system).

sen.j: 元伊勢の伝承を有す。
sen.e: This shrine is believed to be Moto Ise (shrines or places where the deities of Ise Jingu Shrine were once enshrined).
This shrine is believed to be Moto Ise (shrines or places where the deities of Ise Jingu Shrine were once enshrined).
This shrine is believed to be Moto Ise (shrines or places where the deities of Ise Jingu Shrine were once enshrined).

sen.j: 元伊勢「丹波国乃吉佐宮」（『倭姫命世記』）の旧跡であるとの伝承から「元伊勢」を冠して称され、また特に皇大神宮の元宮であるとの伝承から、「元伊勢皇大神宮」或いは「元伊勢内宮」とも称される。
sen.e: As this shrine is reportedly on a historic spot of the Moto Ise "Yosa no miya shrine in Tanba" ("Yamatohime no mikoto seiki"), it is called with the title of "Moto-ise", and also called "Moto Ise Kotai-jingu Shrine" or "Motoise Naiku Shrine" because of the tradition that this shrine is the origin of the Kodai-jingu Shrine.

As this shrine is reportedly on the historic spot of the Moto Ise "Yosa no miya shrine in Tanba" ("Yamatohime no mikoto seiki"), its title is "Moto-ise," and also called "Moto Ise Kotai-jingu Shrine" or "Motoise Naiku Shrine" because of the tradition that this shrine is the origin of the Kodai-jingu Shrine.

As this shrine is reportedly on the historic spot of the Moto Ise 'Yosa no miya shrine in Tanba' ("Yamatohime no mikoto seiki"), its title is 'Moto-ise,' and also called 'Moto Ise Kotai-jingu Shrine' or 'Motoise Naiku Shrine' because of the tradition that this shrine is the origin of the Kodai-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 皇祖神で伊勢の皇大神宮の祭神である天照大神を祀る。
sen.e: This shrine enshrines Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), who is the Kososhin (Imperial ancestor) enshrined by the Kotai-jingu Shrine in Ise.
This shrine enshrines Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), who is the Kososhin (Imperial ancestor) enshrined by the Kotai-jingu Shrine in Ise.
This shrine enshrines Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), who is the Kososhin (Imperial ancestor) enshrined by the Kotai-jingu Shrine in Ise.

sen.j: 『倭姫命世記』に、崇神天皇39年、天照太神を奉じた豊鍬入姫命が鎮座地を求めて但波（丹波）国へ遷幸し、吉佐宮を築いて4年間奉斎したと記す。
sen.e: According to "Yamatohime no mikoto seiki", the Toyosuki iribime no mikoto, who served for Amaterasu Omikami, visited Tanba Province to search for the place to enshrine, built the Yosa-no-miya Shrine and enshrined for four years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）「崇神天皇39年」は西暦年号不明なため割愛しました。「天照太神」は「天照大神」の間違いと解釈して訳出。
sen.e: According to "Yamatohime no mikoto seiki", the Toyosuki iribime no mikoto, who served for Amaterasu Omikami, visited Tanba Province to search for the place to enshrine, built the Yosa-no-miya Shrine and enshrined for four years.

According to "Yamatohime no mikoto seiki," the Toyosuki iribime no mikoto, who served for Amaterasu Omikami, visited Tanba Province to search for the place to enshrine, built the Yosa-no-miya Shrine in 59 B.C. and enshrined for four years.
sen.cmt: カンマの位置移動年号補足

sen.j: 社伝によれば、当神社はその旧跡であり、天照大神が吉佐宮から遷座した後もその神徳を慕った人々が引き続き伊勢神宮内宮の旧跡して崇敬してきたといい、元明天皇（707 - 15年）に社殿を建立したという。
sen.e: As this shrine is reportedly on a historic spot of the Yosa-no-miya Shrine, even after Amaterasu Omikami was transferred, the shrine has been venerated as the remains of Ise-jingu Naiku, and the shrine building has been constructed at the time of Empress Genmei (707 - 715).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）「旧跡して崇拝」⇒「旧跡として崇拝」の誤記と解釈。
sen.e: As this shrine is reportedly on a historic spot of the Yosa-no-miya Shrine, even after Amaterasu Omikami was transferred, the shrine has been venerated as the remains of Ise-jingu Naiku, and the shrine building was constructed at the time of Empress Genmei (707 - 715).

As this shrine is reportedly on a historic spot of the Yosa-no-miya Shrine, even after Amaterasu Omikami was transferred, the shrine has been venerated as the remains of Ise-jingu Naiku, and the shrine building was constructed at the time of Empress Genmei (707 - 715).

sen.j: また、それとは別に、用明天皇の皇子麻呂子親王が当地の兇賊を成敗するに際して勧請したものであるとの異伝もある（宝暦11年（1761年）の『丹後州宮津府志』所引『天橋記』）。
sen.e: There is another legend that Imperial Prince Maroko, the son of Emperor Yomei, enshrined the divided deity to drive off rebels from this place ("Tenkyo-ki" (the Records of Heavenly Bridge) in "The Record of Miyatsu-fu in Tango" in 1761).

There is another legend that Imperial Prince Maroko, the son of Emperor Yomei, enshrined the divided deity to drive off rebels from this place ("Tenkyo-ki" (the Records of Heavenly Bridge) in "The Record of Miyatsu-fu in Tango" in 1761).

There is another legend that Imperial Prince Maroko, the son of Emperor Yomei, enshrined the divided deity to drive off rebels from this place ("Tenkyo-ki" (the Records of Heavenly Bridge) in "The Record of Miyatsu-fu in Tango" in 1761).

sen.j: 近世以前の沿革は不明であるが、江戸時代には4石 (単位)3斗4合の社領を有していた（天和 (日本)元年（1681年）の『宮津領村高帳』）。
sen.e: The history before the early modern ages is unknown, but it possessed the territory with the size of 4-koku (unit) 3-to, and 4-go in the Edo period ("Miyazuryo Muradaka-cho" (the Record of the Total Village Production in Miyazu Domain) of 1681).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割)
sen.e: Its history before the early modern ages is unknown, but it possessed territory with the size of four-koku (unit) three-to, and four-go in the Edo period ("Miyazuryo Muradaka-cho" (the Record of the Total Village Production in Miyazu Domain) of 1681).

Its history before the early modern ages is unknown, but it possessed territory with the size of four-koku (unit) three-to, and four-go in the Edo period ("Miyazuryo Muradaka-cho" (the Record of the Total Village Production in Miyazu Domain) of 1681).

sen.j: 明暦2年（1656年）に宮津藩京極高国が社殿を造営し（社蔵棟札）、元禄14年（1701年）に同奥平昌成も修造してから歴代宮津藩主もこれに倣ったといい、また60年に1度の式年遷宮も行われていた。
sen.e: In 1656 Takakuni KYOGOKU from the Miyazu Domain constructed the shrine building, in 1701 Masashige OKUDAIRA repaired it, and since then the other lords of the Miyazu Domain followed this custom, and the transfer of a deity to a new shrine building was carried out once in 60 years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処（2分割）
sen.e: In 1656, Takakuni KYOGOKU from the Miyazu Domain constructed the shrine building, in 1701 Masashige OKUDAIRA repaired it, and since then the other lords of the Miyazu Domain followed this custom, and the transfer of a deity to a new shrine building was carried out once in 60 years.

In 1656, Takakuni KYOGOKU from the Miyazu Domain constructed the shrine building, in 1701 Masashige OKUDAIRA repaired it, and since then the other lords of the Miyazu Domain followed this custom, and the transfer of a deity to a new shrine building was carried out once in 60 years.

sen.j: 昭和5年（1930年）府社に列し、戦後は神社本庁に参加している。
sen.e: This shrine was classified as Fusha in 1930, and has joined Association of Shinto Shrines after the World War II.
This shrine was classified as Fusha in 1930, and has joined the Association of Shinto Shrines after World War II.
This shrine was classified as Fusha in 1930, and has joined the Association of Shinto Shrines after World War II.

sen.j: 八朔祭（9月1日）
sen.e: Hassaku-sai Festival (September 1)
Hassaku-sai Festival (September 1)
Hassaku-sai Festival (September 1)

sen.j: かつて宮津藩主が祈願のため行列をなして参拝したといい、それに因んで大名行列を模して練り歩く神事（練込）が行われる。
sen.e: It is believed that the lord of Miyazu Domain visited the shrine for praying with a line of people behind him, thus in the ritual ("nerikomi" ritual), people walk imitating the feudal lord's procession.

It is believed that the lord of Miyazu Domain visited the shrine for praying with a line of people behind him, thus in the ritual ("nerikomi" ritual), people walk imitating the feudal lord's procession.

It is believed that the lord of Miyazu Domain visited the shrine for praying with a line of people behind him, thus in the ritual ("nerikomi" ritual), people walk imitating the feudal lord's procession.

sen.j: 古くは「笹囃子」もあったという。
sen.e: In older time, "Sasabayashi dance" was played together.
In older times, "Sasabayashi dance" was played together.
In older times, 'Sasabayashi dance' was played together.

sen.j: 本殿は桁行3間梁間2間の神明造茅葺で、内削ぎの千木を持ち、棟に鰹木を置く。
sen.e: The main shrine is in Shinmei-zukuri style with a thatched roof, and has Ketayuki-sanken (3-ken in length of beam), Harima-niken (2-ken in length of crossbeam), Chigi (ornamental crossbeams on the gable of a Shinto shrine) and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the ridge.

The main shrine is in the Shinmei-zukuri style with a thatched roof, and has Ketayuki-sanken (three-ken in length of beam), Harima-niken (two-ken in length of crossbeam), Chigi (ornamental crossbeams on the gable of a Shinto shrine) and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the ridge.

The main shrine is in the Shinmei-zukuri style with a thatched roof, and has Ketayuki-sanken (three-ken in length of beam), Harima-niken (two-ken in length of crossbeam), Chigi (ornamental crossbeams on the gable of a Shinto shrine) and Katsuogi (ornamental logs arranged orthogonal to the ridge of a Shinto shrine) on the ridge.

sen.j: 本殿を囲む形でコの字形に末社79社が鎮座している。
sen.e: 79 Masshas (small shrines belonging to the main shrine) are surrounding the main shrine in the U shape.
79 Masshas (small shrines belonging to the main shrine) are surrounding the main shrine in a U shape.
79 Masshas (small shrines belonging to the main shrine) are surrounding the main shrine in a U shape.

tit.e: Setsumatsu sha (smaller shrine managed under the shrine)
